title: 10 Signs You're in a Toxic Work Environment + What to Do Next | Career Contessa
description: Toxic work environments are a drain on your personal and professional life. Here are ten common signs of a toxic workplace—and how to navigate (or escape) them.

A Toxic Workplace May Have Poor Communication [communication skills](https://careercontessa.teachable.com/p/interpersonal-communication-101/)are the most important skills needed in any successful organization. Why? [listening skills](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/types-of-listening/)(both as a manager and an employee), verbal communication, written communication, preferences on how to communicate—the list goes on! - Overall lack of communication is a core issue - Constant lack of clarity around projects - Different employees receive different messages [Passive-aggressive communication](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/coworkers-passive-aggressive-behavior/) - Weak [listening skills](https://www.careercontessa.com/resources/better-listening-skills/) - Constant "off-hours" communication [Communication](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/soft-skills-definition/)is the root cause of bad organizations—or good organizations operating poorly. Bad communication often leads to confusion and a lack of purpose for employees. From here, problems arise and compound, often leading to all the other items on our list. 2. A Toxic Workplace May Have Cliques, Exclusion + Gossipy Behavior [workplace bullies](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/problem-coworkers/), or exclusionary groups. Nobody wants to go back to middle school, no matter how good the benefits might be. - Constant feeling of exclusion from a group of people - A particular group of toxic employees that lunches, grabs coffee, and organizes happy hours together - Projects often are offered to a particular group, regardless of talent or experience - Large parts of the workday are spent whispering or chatting on messaging platforms - General outward disinterest from the group in anyone else—unless it involves gossip or "drama" [Avoid coworkers that gossip](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/problem-coworkers/). Don't engage in rumors or hearsay. They have no place at work. 3. A Toxic Workplace May Have Bad Leadership [eleven types of bad bosses](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/i-hate-my-boss/)and how to handle them, but here's the thing... [a micromanaging boss](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/i-hate-my-boss/#micromanager)who constantly corrects you, undermines your decisions, and ultimately disallows you from doing your job. [the "Blame Game" boss](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/i-hate-my-boss/#blame), who is quick to pass mistakes on to anyone but themselves. Or, you might be lucky enough to have [the "No Respect" boss](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/i-hate-my-boss/#respect), who emails at all hours, forgets how to spell your name, and likely doesn't even know what you do. [bad boss](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/i-hate-my-boss/)has a pretty decent boss—you can try communicating these issues. 4. A Toxic Workplace Likely Has Unmotivated Coworkers [unmotivated coworkers](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/how-to-motivate-yourself/), it's going to take its toll on you. You might have two reactions to unmotivated coworkers. - You're going to shoulder a ton of work that they aren't handling—and find yourself [burnt out](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/recover-from-burnout/) - Their lack of motivation is going to bum you out—and burn you out with a type of [underchallenged burnout](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/recover-from-burnout/) [motivate you to work harder](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/how-to-motivate-yourself/), be better, and incubate new ideas, they can wear you down. Unmotivated employees are usually a result of a much larger organizational problem. 5. A Toxic Workplace May Have Stifled Growth [learning opportunities for advancing your skills](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/continuing-education-online-courses/)or career, or mentorship, they are likely not invested in the growth of their employees. Once you've recognized that you have nowhere to grow, it might be time to change the soil. [job itself isn't always responsible for inspiring](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/good-enough-job/)and motivating you. However, if you feel completely stuck with nowhere to grow, it might be time for you to move on. 6. A Toxic Workplace Likely Has Rapid Employee Turnover [Leaving a job](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/quitting-with-reputation-reference/)is a tough decision to make. When you notice that several people are making that decision, then something is really rotten. [being laid off](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/how-to-negotiate-severance/)or fired, this can be a sign of a few other toxic elements. 7. A Toxic Workplace Often Has No Work-Life Balance [setting healthy work boundaries](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/healthy-boundaries-at-work/). If your boundaries can't be met, or at least compromised, it's probably not for you. 8. A Toxic Workplace Leaves You Battling Burnout [Workplace burnout](https://www.careercontessa.com/advice/recover-from-burnout/)is recognized by the World Health Organization as a legitimate medical diagnosis. - Frenetic Burnout: Frenetic burnout is experienced by employees who put a ton of energy into their work in the hopes that the output will be rewarding. After a sustained period of dedicated work, the frenetic worker does not find positive outcomes. - Underchallenged Burnout: This type of burnout occurs when an employee feels underchallenged and bored at work. Being unable to find any satisfaction in a job, the underchallenged employees find themselves in a lowered mood. - Worn-out Burnout: The worn-out employee is someone who is resigned about their work after experiencing consistent work stress over a long period of time. Having experienced negligible rewards, the worn-out employee feels disillusioned and uninspired by the job at hand. 9.
